text:
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name ... Harry ... F. O. D.
Address ... Humboldt, Sask.
Birthplace ... Attleborough, Staffordshire, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1903
Where did you set up housekeeping? Regina at Humboldt
Where had you been living before that? England
For how many people did you prepare meals? 7
How far was it to your nearest store? 4 blocks
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every day
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Rolled oats, tea, coffee, syrup, lard, sugar, dried apples.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? 1903
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? 60 miles What year? 1904
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00
What other grain products did you use? None
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it?
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Ska., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: Harry Ford
Address: Humboldt, Sask.
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1903
Where did you set up housekeeping? Regina, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? England
For how many people did you prepare meals? 7
How far was it to your nearest store? 4 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every day, every 3 months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Bread, sugar, flour, coffee, tea, apples

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Red River Mill
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use Graham flour? None
Was flour milled locally? No
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00
What other grain products did you use? Whole Wheat, Parina
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
How did you grind it?
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy this sugar? ........................................... 16 lb.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 16¢ per lb.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...........................................

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...........................................

At what price? .......................................................................................

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ..........................

We bought a cow with us from Virginia.

Butter? ...................................................................................................

That was the price of butter? 15¢ per lb.

Did you make butter? .............................................................................

Did you make cheese? ............................................................................

What kind of cheese? .............................................................................

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...........................................

Pork, chicken, and ducks.

How did you get fresh meat? .....................................................................

How often did you get fresh meat? ...........................................................

How did you preserve meat? .....................................................................

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ......................................

If so what year was it organized? .............................................................

Did you use games? ................................................................................

For how long? ........................................................................................

What part did fish play in the family diet? Very little.

Just used in soups.

Was the fish fresh, canned, or smoked? ...................................................

Kind? .......................................................... Jacks and white fish.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Gold Standard at what price? $3.46
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground
Price? $.60 $.15 That other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? 30 cents
Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes
If not, where from?
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1919 Cabbage 1919 Carrots 1919 Onions 1919
Turnips 1919 Beets 1919
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk
What weight? 8 lbs How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?
What was the price of prunes? $1.60
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, peaches, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes
Peas? Yes Corn? No Beans? Yes Saskatoons? No
Other foods?
That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1910
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1910
That year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1910
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes but
To what extent?
Did you make your own vinegar? No
6. What kind of tea did you buy? 
   - Black tea
   - Green tea
   - Herbal tea

7. Vegetables and Fruits

   - Could you grow potatoes at the school?
     - Yes
     - No

   - If yes, where from?
     - Own garden
     - Market

   - Last year did you grow your own supply for the market?
     - Yes
     - No

   - Potatoes
     - Carrots
     - Turnips
     - Beets

   - In what quantities did you buy this year?
     - Bulk
     - Box

   - How did you buy it?
     - Market
     - Grocery store

   - What was the price per pound?
     - $

   - What other dried foods did you use in the last month?
     - Apples
     - Peaches
     - Raisins
     - Grapes

8. Preserves

   - In the last year did you make any preserves by yourself?
     - Yes
     - No

   - Where did you buy them?
     - Market
     - Grocery store

   - What year did you first make preserves?
     - $

   - Do you still make preserves by yourself?
     - Yes
     - No

   - Did you make your own preserves?
     - Yes
     - No

| Macaroni              | 1910                                          | Box                                              | None                               |                     |

| Lily white syrup      | 1918                                          |                                                 | 5                                  | 25¢                 |
| Toilet soap           | 1910                                          | Box                                              | 7                                  | 25¢                 |
| Baking powder         | 1910                                          | Can                                              | 1 lb.                              |                     |
| Baking soda           | 1910                                          | Can                                              | 1 lb.                              |                     |
| Dried peas            |                                               |                                                  |                                    |                     |

| Store jam - kinds?    |                                               |                                                  |                                    |                     |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | 1910 | Bulk | 2 lb. | 30¢ |
| Vanilla               |                                               |                                                  |                                    |                     |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal

Did you make yeast for your own use? No

Using hops? No

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? No

Baking soda? No

Cream of tartar? No

Did you make your own baking powder? No
| Food                  | Year | Bulk | Price |
|-----------------------|------|------|-------|
| Soda bicarbonate      | 1910 | 12c   | 25¢   |
| Macaroni              | 1914 | 2c    | 25¢   |
| Graham flour          | 1914 | 2c    | 25¢   |
| Brown sugar           | 1910 | 14¢   | 10¢   |
| Lollipops             | 1912 | 16¢-18¢ | 10¢   |
| Table salt            | 1904 | 2c    | 25¢   |
| Butter                | 1911 | 13¢   | 25¢   |
| Tollott soap          | 1910 | 13¢   | 25¢   |
| Baking powder         | 1910 | 13¢   | 25¢   |
| Baking soda           | 1910 | 13¢   | 25¢   |
| Dried peas            |      |       |       |
| Dried corn            | 1905 | 19¢   | 25¢   |
| Yeast                 | 1905 | 3¢    | 25¢   |
| Raisins               | 1905 | 3¢    | 25¢   |
| Raisins               | 1905 | 3¢    | 25¢   |
| Rice                  | 1905 | 3¢    | 25¢   |
| Currants              | 1905 | 3¢    | 25¢   |
| Store jam - kirsch    |      |       |       |
| Choose (Graham or store cheese) | 1910 | 2¢    | 25¢   |
| Vanilla               |      |       |       |

10. Baking

What type of yeast did you use? No
Did you make yeast for your own use? No
Using hops? No
Salt rising? No
Did you buy baking powder? No
Did you take your own baking powder? No
Green of tartar? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ........................................ Well ................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ......................................................... about 300 yards ..........................................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................................... Barrel ................................................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, stream, dugout)

If so far was this water from your house? About 300 feet.

How was it brought to the house? (Pail, barrel, tank)

Has any change been made in your water supply? Mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

First started homesteading...
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ..............................................
If you made your own, did you use lye? ..............................................
Wood ashes? ..............................................
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ..............................................

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ..............................................
Where did you get your fuel? ..............................................
..............................................

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

About 1928 we had to use coal.
Fuel oils are being used quite a lot in this district. And recently some cooking is done by electricity.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ..............................................
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ..............................................
No ..............................................

By whom was your first cook stove made? ..............................................
What year was it purchased? ..............................................
Price? ..............................................

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ..............................................
Tin ..............................................

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ..............................................
China ..............................................

When did you first see enamel ware? ..............................................
1916 ..............................................

Aluminum? ..............................................
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? We made our own.

If you used your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kind of laundry soap did the presser handle?

14. FUEL

That fuel did you use in the earliest days? Kerosene.

Have you not your old fuel?

Ration any changes in the use of fuels. Which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

About 1928 we had to cut back the fuel oils on them until we could get something else.

In this district, hardworking women worked to save by electricity.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or an outdoor fireplace out in your yard? (Give dates.) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates.)

By then was your first cook stove ready? No.

When was it purchased? 1928.

Price? $9.20.

For preparing food? (chips, earthenware, modern berries, other)

Then did you first see using aluminum? 1928.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Prairie Bread & butter eggs. Tea
Dinner: Prairie chicken, potatoes, cabbage. Water
Supper: Prairie chicken, potatoes, bread
dried apples. Tea

Harry Ford Jan. 1903
Helena Ford

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Turkey with Pheasant stuffing and plum pudding
This was 1903 and seven young men looked for the winner
J. J. Hill 21
Harry Grant 23
Harry Ford 22
Bob Hunt 22
Harry Helme 27
John Price 26
Fred Bradshaw 27

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

In 1904 there was a period of two days when all the flour was gone in many homes in this district caused by bad roads when we had to fetch our supplies from Northern
17. Give a typical dinner menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year (1893). Include the following: breakfast, dinner, and supper. 

Breakfast:
- Pancake Bread
- Baked Eggs
- Coffee

Dinner:
- Roast Chicken Potatoes
- Gravy
- Dinner Rolls

Supper:
- Meat Loaf
- Green Beans
- Rolls

January 2nd, 1904.

Helena

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Helena? 

19. How many people attended? Give the names, ages, jobs, present and past skills, approximate area at that time.

Jackie's work: File clerk, typed for the county.

This was in 1903 and there were 15 men, 1 woman, 1 child.

1st: Mr. Hill
2nd: Mrs. Smith
3rd: Mrs. Johnson
4th: Mr. Kelso
5th: Mr. Birdshaus

In 1904, there was a period of two days when all the snow was gone and we could go outside. After that, we had to stay inside because it was too cold outside.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, Bread & butter eggs, tea
Dinner: Rame chicken, potatoes, cabbage, water
Supper: Rame chicken, potatoes, bread, dried apples, tea

Henry Ford Jan. 1909
Helena Ford

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Turkey with stuffing and plum pudding
This was 1903 and seven young men looked for the writer
J. J. Hill 21 Harry Grant 23
Henry Ford 22 Bob Hunt 22
Henry Helme 27 John Price 26
Fred Bradshaw 27

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

In 1904 there was a period of two days when all the flour was gone in many homes in this district caused by bad roads when we had to fetch our supplies from Northern
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the number of family members or names at the time. State the approximate number.

Breakfast:
- Pancake Bread
- Butter
- Coffee

Supper:
- Roast Chicken
- Potatoes
- Gravy
- Apple Pie

Henry Ford
Jan. 1903

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Kansas?

January 1903
Henry Ford 23
Henry Welme 27
Fred Bredehoeft 27

19. Were you ever rationed to almost starvation level living on one or two days' local produce? Give details.

In 1904 there was a period of two months when all the flour was gone in many homes in Atchison due to lack of supplies from Missouri.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the pioneer days our wives in helping to make a home did not have the time to give us much variation, just plain food. Today we can buy everything necessary such as more fruits and canned goods.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Since 1930 we have purchased some prepared foods, but still rely mainly on what we produce on the farm.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of stores, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In the early years, our needs were very small for luxuries. Xmas presents for the children were nearly all hand made. The stores were not very well equipped so it was a matter generally of buying what was in stock, generally speaking very few settlers had any cash.
21. Then did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

Since 1930 we have purchased more purchased foods that will only mean purchased foods that will produce on the farm or what we produce on the farm.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways, further plans laid in securing foods. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, etc., characters encountered, prices paid, etc.

In the early years our needs were very small for these reasons. When purchased foods were readily available well very well supplied. We were not very well supplied so we were smarter ourselves of purchasing what was on hand. Finally when very dry weather had any effect...
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the pioneer days our wives in helping to make a home did not have the time to give us much variation, just plain food. Today we can buy everything necessary, such as more fruits and canned goods.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Since 1930 we have purchased some prepared foods, but still rely mainly on what we produce on the farm.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In the early years our needs were very small for luxuries. Xmas presents for the children were nearly all hand made. The stores were not very well equipped so it was a matter generally of taking what was in stock. Generally speaking very few settlers had any cash.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of mails in the
correspondence above the company's usual tally.

In the former days our work was done in keeping to the time
in a manner that did not harm the time to you in
a much particular; just plain work and
so day we can say every thing necessary.
To day we can do more things and consume goods
such as more flowers and consume goods

Since 1930 we have purchased some
prepared goods. We will rely mainly
on what we produce on the farm

21. When did you begin working at Ford?

and securing foods in your early Indiana days in Terre Haute, Indiana.
Include problems of storage, quality, methods of purchasing,
prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details.

for their size. They had made

so we were smaller generally speaking
not even six inches tall and any pack
